comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: G.C. Gow seems likely to be a professor of music at Vassar and composer. George Coleman Gow -- see imslp.org/wiki/Category:Gow,_George_Coleman More biography at grandemusica.net/musical-biographies-g-2/gow-george-coleman

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A. Bergh could then be en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Bergh Arthur Oscar Bergh (March 24, 1882 – February 11, 1962) also a composer.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: M. M. Marks seems to be en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcus_M._Marks who would have been Manhattan Borough President in 1915. He is best known as President of the Daylight Saving Assocation

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Since two seem to be composers, perhaps Schleider is in fact Schlieder -- Schlieder, Frederick William 1873-1953 www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-no93-31418 New-York tribune., October 10, 1915, Page 8 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-10-10/ed-... confirms his identity with a picture.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Schlieder and Gow were both active in the New York State Music Teachers Association.  So perhaps this could have been during a meeting of the association

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The June 18, 1915 New York Times has an article about the conclusion the night before of the New York State Music Teachers' Association's annual convention the night before. Frederick Schlieder had been re-elected president, Bergh and Gow are not mentioned. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0B10F9395B1773...

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: swanq and artolog:  Thanks for the  identifications of the composers in this image.  We will add more to the descriptions when we update.   We can also add that the scene is possibly related to the New York State Music Teachers'  Association convention in 1915.

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I created the entry in Wikipedia for Marcus M. Marks last time he came around in a set.
